channel.title: Home on Slumdown
channel.description: Recent content in Home on Slumdown

item.title: Tutorial part 1: Getting started
item.description: A sort summary of how to get started using the slumdown package. It discusses how to install the package, set up a new site, and where to look for initial configuration.

item.title: Tutorial part 2: Writing a post
item.description: Like any blogdown post, a slumdown post is written in R Markdown, and uses a few custom fields in the YAML field. This tutorial provides an illustration of how different kinds of content are displayed.

item.title: Tutorial part 3: Colour palettes in slumdown
item.description: The main reason I wrote slumdown (besides boredom) was to make it easy to include user-defined colours palettes in blogdown, and expose those palettes to R so that (for instance) plots can be drawn in a style that matches the blog style. This tutorial introduces this palette system.

item.title: Tutorial part 4: Customising the header
item.description: Slumdown allows the user to control the background image at the top of each post, the profile image overlaid in the middle of that image, and the caption attached to the header image. This post describes how this is done.

item.title: Tutorial part 5: Deploying to GitHub
item.description: This tutorial describes how to deploy a site. Blogdown sites are very often deployed to Netlify, but I have a personal bias to use GitHub Pages, so slumdown is configured by default to use GitHub.

item.title: Tutorial part 6: Some notes on Hugo
item.description: Eventually, this will be an explanation of how the Hugo slum theme is designed, possibly accompanied by a brief tutorial on Hugo.

item.title: A kunoichi page
item.description: A simple project page illustrating how user-defined themes in slumdown can be used as the basis of individual pages and ggplot2 figures. It doesn’t do very much.

item.title: About
item.description: The idea behind slumdown The slum theme for Hugo and blogdown is an adaptation Yihue Xieâ€™s Xmin theme that borrows stylistic elements from the Tufte R Markdown theme and from the academic Hugo theme. Originally it was intended to be extremely minimal, with the very modest goal of trying to make sure I understood the logic of how Hugo generates static sites. The more I played with it though, the more I enjoyed it.
